clean_story: Towers of cooled air.  Nature’s silent air conditioners. "Termite mound" describes the towering, clay-built nests where millions of termites live—yet their real genius is invisible. Inside, a labyrinth of tunnels and chimneys works like a building’s HVAC, but without electricity. Here’s the mechanism:Hot air rises from the nest’s core,  pulling fresh oxygen down through porous walls. At night, cooler outside air sinks into lower chambers,  flushing out carbon dioxide. The secret?The mound’s spongy, moisture-rich clay—it absorbs heat by day,  releases it at night. Like a desert canteen sweating to stay cool. Architects now mimic this. Zimbabwe’s Eastgate Centre uses termite-inspired vents and thermal mass,  slashing energy costs by 90%. No AC units—just adjustable flaps and thick walls that "breathe. "Three related subjects are biomimicry in architecture, passive cooling techniques, and how ants farm fungi underground.
